activities.text: The thermal walk through the town reveals Auvergne architecture of stone and lauze (schist slate) roofs. Touch the warm water in the restored fountains, discover the hot-water wash house fed by the Lestande spring (62°C), and warm up in winter in the Saint-Martin-Saint-Blaise church heated through the floor by geothermal springs. The "De Par en Par" trail guides you through this unique thermal heritage.

Hiking on the Aubrac plateau is a must at the gates of Chaudes-Aigues. These vast wild highland spaces reveal lush pastures, traditional burons and herds of Aubrac cattle in a preserved mid-mountain landscape. Waymarked trails offer panoramas stretching to the Truyère gorges and the Cantal mountains.

visits.text: The old town of Vic-sur-Cère nestles against the east slope of the valley at 680 metres altitude, sheltered by a spectacular rocky and wooded chaos. Built of lava stone and roofed with schist slabs, this spa village retains the authentic charm of Cantal mountain towns. A renowned climatic resort, it offers a green setting ideal for recharging.

The Rocher des Pendus towers over Vic-sur-Cère and offers an exceptional viewpoint over the upper valley. The nearby Puy Griou rises before the Élancèze and the Peyre-Arse in a grandiose panorama over the Cantal summits. This perspective reveals the full majesty of the volcanic cirque.

activities.text: The Cascades du Pas de Cère tumble through a spectacular canyon where tumultuous water has carved the volcanic rock. The fitted trail follows the gorges in a cool, green atmosphere, revealing successive waterfalls in an impressive mineral setting. The roar of water echoes between the basaltic walls.

The Pas de Cère canyon offers thrill-seekers a canyoning descent through the wild gorges. Jumps, natural slides and rappels follow one another in the riverbed between vertical walls of black lava. Local outfitters supervise this spectacular aquatic activity.

visits.text: The old town of Riom-ès-Montagnes spreads its historic houses around the parish church in the atmosphere of an authentic mountain town. The nerve centre of the Gentian country, this small town retains the character of Cantal villages where lava stone bears witness to the territory's volcanic origins.

The Maison de la Gentiane et des Plantes d'Auvergne reveals the secrets of this iconic plant with its yellow root that grows on high-altitude pastures. Interactive museography, a botanical garden and an educational distillery trace the history of the artisanal harvest and transformation into liqueur. The yellow gentian, hand-picked on the summer pastures, remains a powerful symbol of mountain Auvergne.

activities.text: A visit to a gentian distillery reveals the ancestral techniques for producing the famous liqueur. The roots macerate for several years before distillation to release their characteristic bitter aromas. A comparative tasting between different expressions (Avèze, Salers Gentiane) allows you to appreciate the nuances of this quintessentially Auvergnat spirit.

Hiking on the plateau offers beautiful escapes through summer pasture landscapes where Salers cattle graze. These vast green expanses dotted with abandoned burons tell the pastoral story of Cantal. Trails wind between heather moors and flowering meadows with views of the surrounding mountains.

visits.text: The Basilique Notre-Dame-des-Miracles rises at the heart of Mauriac, a sanctuary founded in the 6th century by Théodechilde, daughter of Clovis. The sculpted Romanesque portal of the 12th century announces the majesty of the building. Inside, the Gothic choir and the relics of Saint Marius (an evangelizing disciple whose name is said to have inspired "Puy Mary") bear witness to the age-old religious influence of this town between the Dordogne and the Cantal mountains.

The old town retains the charm of Auvergne market towns with its bourgeois houses, shaded small squares and volcanic stone façades. Stroll through the lanes climbing towards the basilica, discover the local shops and the peaceful atmosphere of this Cantal sub-prefecture with its preserved character.

activities.text: The weekly market brings the central square to life in a bustle of colours and flavours. Farm producers, market gardeners and artisans offer aged cheeses, local cured meats, sourdough breads and seasonal vegetables. The perfect opportunity to meet passionate farmers and taste Cantal's authenticity.

The walk to the Château d'Anjony reveals one of the finest castles in Cantal, a 15th-century medieval fortress overlooking the Doire valley. Its four corner towers frame a remarkable square keep. The Renaissance frescoes in the chapel and the wall paintings in the apartments are exceptional artistic treasures within this austere military setting.

seo.h1_title: Cantal Road Trip: Auvergne Volcanoes and Mountain Traditions
seo.intro_paragraph: Discover Europe's largest stratovolcano through its villages of character: Salers and its Renaissance lava-stone houses, Saint-Flour perched on its basaltic plateau, Puy Mary and its 360° panorama, and the 82°C hot springs of Chaudes-Aigues. Between majestic summits and pastoral traditions, Cantal reveals an authentic Auvergne where lava stone tells 13 million years of geological history.
seo.seo_hook: Glacial valleys radiate from Puy Mary, hot springs bubble at 82°C, black lava villages crown the plateaux. Cantal is Europe's sleeping volcanic giant.
featured_list: Puy Mary: volcanic pyramid with 360° panorama
Salers: Renaissance village in black lava stone
Saint-Flour: Europe's highest cathedral by altitude

places_taglines.FR::salers: Renaissance jewel in black lava stone
places_taglines.FR::murat: basaltic spur at the foot of Bonnevie
places_taglines.FR::mauriac: basilica of miracles between Dordogne and Cantal

highlights: Puy Mary (1,787 m): Grand Site de France with 360° panorama over Europe's largest stratovolcano
Salers: Most Beautiful Village of France in black lava stone with PDO cheese
Source du Par in Chaudes-Aigues: 82°C, Europe's hottest spring
Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Saint-Flour: Europe's highest Gothic cathedral by altitude (892 m)

itineraries.title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days
itineraries.subtitle: From centuries-old cellars to Romanesque churches, the Charente between vineyards and river

visits.text: The Cité internationale de la BD occupies a former warehouse on the banks of the Charente. Over 20,000 original comic plates, cutting-edge temporary exhibitions, and Europe's largest comic book library. Allow 2 hours to make the most of it.

The Cathédrale Saint-Pierre is Romanesque, not Gothic — and that changes everything. The sculpted 12th-century façade tells the story of the Ascension and the Last Judgement across 70 stone figures. The contemporary Treasury by Jean-Michel Othoniel is worth a detour.

The ramparts walk offers a full panorama over the Charente below. Angoulême sits on a rocky spur — you can see why it served as a stronghold. It's also the best vantage point for spotting the comic book murals.
Over 30 monumental murals across the streets: Titeuf on a gable end, Lucky Luke at a crossroads, Blake and Mortimer round a corner. Free map at the tourist office. Kids love it — adults too.

Under the Halles centrales, producers sell pineau, rillettes and cagouilles (local snails). Around them, cobbled lanes climb towards the town hall housed in the former comtal castle. Good bistros in the area.

activities.text: Guided tour 'Comics in the City'. The guides know the stories behind every mural: who painted what, why there, the hidden details. Duration 1h30, departure from the tourist office.

practical_info.booking: Booking recommended in summer and during the Festival

activities.text: Walk along the Charente riverbanks. The towpath runs from the Cité BD along the river. Canoe hire available at the watersports centre in season. Quieter option: traditional gabare boat with commentary.
Musée d'Angoulême in the former bishop's palace, behind the cathedral. Varied collections: Charente archaeology (the famous gold Agris helmet), African arts, regional paintings. Small but well done.

visits.text: The Château de La Rochefoucauld has belonged to the same family since 1019 — a French record. The three-storey Renaissance galleries recall Italian palaces. Legend has it the spiral staircase was designed by Leonardo da Vinci.
The castle's four libraries hold 21,000 volumes. The guided tour (compulsory for this section) includes the Treasury room where the guide handles eight-century-old archives. Impressive.

The town at the foot of the castle is worth a stroll: half-timbered houses, cobbled lanes along the Tardoire. This is where the charentaise slipper was born — the shoe, not the resident. Specialist shop on Rue des Halles.

activities.text: Full castle visit. Self-guided section (salons, kitchens, galleries) + guided tour of the libraries and archives. Allow 2 hours total. Children can dress up as knights or princesses — costumes provided.

practical_info.tickets: At the wine merchant at the bottom of the drive
practical_info.tip: Children's costumes available free of charge

activities.text: Chocolaterie d'Antan at the foot of the castle. Watch artisans at work from the shop. Local speciality: the pichotte, a chocolate-almond-icing sugar sweet. Open even on Sundays.
Hike along the Tardoire. Waymarked trails from the castle into the rolling countryside. Landscapes that hint at the neighbouring Périgord. Several loops from 5 to 15 km.

visits.text: The Pont-Vieux in Confolens has spanned the Vienne since the 11th century (on ancient foundations). Postcard view of half-timbered houses reflected in the water. This is where the Goire meets the Vienne — hence the name 'confluent'.
The old town climbs the hill in winding lanes. Medieval half-timbered houses, craft shops, small shaded squares. The Saint-Barthélemy quarter keeps its old-world atmosphere.
The church of Saint-Maxime overlooks the upper town. Sculpted Romanesque doorway, square bell tower typical of Poitou. Inside, carved historiated capitals and contemporary stained glass. Free entry.

activities.text: Walk along the Vienne. The towpath leads from the Old Bridge towards the countryside. Anglers, grey herons, abandoned locks. Peaceful atmosphere guaranteed.
Canoeing on the Vienne. The watersports centre offers routes from 2 hours to a full day. Calm water, no technical difficulty. Hire includes life jackets and dry bags.

Confolens Festival (mid-August). Since 1958, France's biggest folklore festival. Troupes from around the world, costumed parades, free concerts. If you're passing through at this time, it's unmissable.

visits.text: The Château de Verteuil has overlooked the village from its rocky spur for centuries. Owned by the La Rochefoucauld family for 1,000 years (sold in 2020), it hosted Charles V who planted a yew still standing today. Visit the chapel and main courtyard.
The Moulin de Verteuil at the foot of the castle, with its waterwheel still turning. Now a restaurant with a terrace by the water. The castle + mill + Charente view = the perfect photo.

The church of Saint-Médard (12th century) hides a life-size Entombment in polychrome terracotta. Seven figures around Christ, attributed to the workshop of Germain Pilon. One of the Charente's hidden treasures.

The village lanes lead to the fairground shaded by lime trees, on the banks of the Charente. The Maison du Sénéchal (15th century) with its mullioned windows, remains of the old Protestant temple, wash houses. A Petite Cité de Caractère.

activities.text: Castle visit. Access to the main courtyard and chapel (self-guided or guided depending on availability). Tickets from the wine merchant at the bottom of the drive.

practical_info.tickets: At the Jeux de Pots wine shop
practical_info.open: Check opening hours, closed some days

activities.text: Lunch at the Moulin de Verteuil. Terrace facing the waterwheel, local cuisine. Booking advised at weekends. Alternative: Jeux de Pots overlooks the Charente.

practical_info.reservation: Advised at weekends and in summer

activities.text: Hike around the castle. 6.6 km loop through the countryside and hamlets, returning along the Charente banks. Easy, 1h30–2h. Start from the castle car park.

visits.text: The Hennessy house offers the most spectacular tour: solar-powered boat crossing of the Charente, ageing cellars where the 'angel's share' floats in the air, guided tasting. Booking essential.

Martell, the oldest of the great houses (1715), has renovated its historic site with its Art Deco tower. Tour of the centuries-old cellars and the founder's house. A more intimate atmosphere than Hennessy.
The Château de Cognac, birthplace of Francis I, houses Baron Otard cognacs. Renaissance vaulted cellars, rooftop view over the Charente. French history entwined with the story of cognac.
Old Cognac is best explored on foot: medieval houses with walls blackened by the cognac fungus (the famous Torula), merchants' townhouses, quays where gabares loaded barrels.
The Musée des Arts du Cognac traces the history of this spirit: stills, cooperage, vintage labels, retro advertisements. A good complement to cellar tours. Housed in two townhouses.

activities.text: Tour of a major cognac house. Hennessy for the immersive experience, Martell for intimacy, Rémy Martin for connoisseurs (expert tours available). Allow 1h30 to 2h including tasting.
Cruise on the Charente. Traditional gabares with commentary (1h30) or licence-free electric boat hire. The river at the pace of the barrels of old.
Cycling along the Charente. The Flow Vélo (national route) passes through Cognac. Bike hire available in town. Flat route to Jarnac (15 km) or Saint-Brice (8 km).

visits.text: The Courvoisier house stands in its château on the banks of the Charente. Tour of the cellars including the famous 'Paradis' where the oldest eaux-de-vie age. Tasting overlooking the river.
The church of Saint-Pierre blends eras: 11th-century Romanesque foundations, a 12th-century crypt where the former Counts of Jarnac rest, later alterations. Tombs of the local lords in the crypt.

The Musée Donation François-Mitterrand occupies a former warehouse. State gifts received during his terms: paintings, sculptures, ceramics from around the world. The former president was born here and rests here.
The Jarnac quays line up trading houses and bourgeois residences. The Charente flows peacefully, white façades reflected in the water. Starting point for river cruises.

activities.text: Tour of the Courvoisier house. More low-key than the Cognac giants, with a family feel. The 'Paradis' cellar holds century-old eaux-de-vie. Tasting included.
River cruise Jarnac–Cognac. Licence-free barge for the day or guided gabare. The river winds between vineyards and villages. Manual locks, contemplative pace.
Visit to François Mitterrand's birthplace. The house where the former president was born in 1916. Guided tour by appointment, intimate atmosphere.

visits.text: The medieval castle of Châteauneuf has vanished. Only the name and presumed site near the current fairground remain. However, the Logis de Barqueville (15th century) facing the church forms a handsome ensemble with the square. Pleasant walk along the shaded riverbanks.

The church of Saint-Pierre (12th century) boasts one of the finest façades in the Charente: three sculpted tiers, a horseman representing Constantine crushing paganism. Inside, carved Romanesque capitals and a little snail hidden in high relief.
The river port brings the town to life. A stop on the Charente for pleasure boaters and canoeists. Café terraces, shaded picnic area. Watersports centre in summer.

activities.text: Canoeing on the Charente. The watersports centre hires kayaks and canoes with return shuttle. Routes from 2 hours to a full day. Calm water, swimming possible at designated stops.

practical_info.includes: Life jackets, dry bag, return shuttle

activities.text: Swimming at the Bain des Dames. The leisure area, labelled Station Sport Nature, has the only supervised beach on the Charente in the Cognac area. Lawn, toilets, snack bar. Free.
Fishing on the Charente. Quiet spots upstream and downstream of town. Zander, pike, carp. Daily fishing licence available at the tobacconist.

visits.text: The underground church of Saint-Jean is the largest in Europe: 27 m long, 16 m wide, nearly 20 m high, carved into the cliff in the 12th century. Monumental nave, reliquary hewn from the rock, some 170 tombs in the floor. Stunning.

The church of Saint-Jacques at the top of the village: Romanesque façade with Hispano-Moorish carvings, a reminder of the pilgrims passing through on the Way to Compostela. Finely chiselled archivolt portal.

The village tiers like an amphitheatre above the Dronne. Cobbled lanes, white houses with tiled roofs, Spanish-style flower-decked balconies. Classified as one of the Most Beautiful Villages of France since 1993.
The Place Ludovic Trarieux, heart of the village, honours the founder of the League of Human Rights, born here. Lime-tree-shaded terraces, shops, artisans. The spot for a coffee.

activities.text: Visit the monolithic church. Open year-round except 25 Dec and 1 Jan. Bring a layer — it's cool inside. The exceptional acoustics occasionally draw concerts.
Swimming in the Dronne. The managed beach below the village has sand, a shaded lawn, slides. Lifeguards in summer. Canoe hire on site.
Canoeing on the Dronne. Gentle routes from the village base. Clear water, wooded banks. Return by shuttle.
Artisan workshops. The village is home to potters, painters, sculptors. Open studio-shops in summer. One-off pieces, meet the creators.

visits.text: The Château de Villebois-Lavalette crowns its hilltop with seven round towers visible for miles. Medieval fortress reworked during the Renaissance, two-storey Romanesque chapel. Guided or self-guided tour with booklet.
The 17th-century covered market hall stands against the castle walls. Chestnut timber frame, stone pillars. On Saturday mornings, the market comes alive: cheeses, poultry, garden vegetables.
The village retains some fine old houses, a restored Romanesque church, and an end-of-the-world feel. At the far edge of the Charente, the Périgord is only a few kilometres away.

activities.text: Guided tour of the Château de Villebois-Lavalette. The association's guides bring history to life: two-storey Romanesque chapel (pilgrims below, lords above), medieval towers, 17th-century residence. Family escape games available.
Saturday morning market. Under the 17th-century hall, local producers and village atmosphere. Goat's cheese, free-range chickens, seasonal vegetables, honey. A real country market.

practical_info.tip: Arrive before 10 am for the best choice

activities.text: Hike around Villebois. Waymarked trails through wooded hills. Mixed-farming landscapes, isolated farms, views of the castle. Several loops from 5 to 12 km.
Drive back to Angoulême on back roads. Through southern Charente: vineyards, honey-stone villages, rolling hills. 40 km in about an hour at a gentle pace.

seo.h1_title: Charente Circuit: Cognac and Romanesque Heritage in 9 Days
seo.intro_paragraph: From the cognac cellars to Renaissance castles, from the comic book murals of Angoulême to the underground church of Aubeterre: the Charente marries the art of living with a thousand years of heritage. A leisurely circuit along the river, between tastings and character villages.
seo.seo_hook: Cognac ages in centuries-old cellars, Romanesque churches stand against the blue sky, the Charente flows at its own pace. A journey at the rhythm of eau-de-vie.
featured_list: Cognac: tour of the great houses, boat crossing, tasting
Angoulême: comic book capital, Romanesque cathedral, painted walls
La Rochefoucauld: Renaissance castle inhabited for 1,000 years
Aubeterre-sur-Dronne: church carved into the rock, Most Beautiful Village of France

places_taglines.FR::angouleme: comic book capital perched on its rock
places_taglines.FR::la-rochefoucauld: a thousand years of history in a Renaissance castle
places_taglines.FR::confolens: old bridge and half-timbered houses on the Vienne
places_taglines.FR::cognac: birthplace of the world's most famous spirit
places_taglines.FR::villebois-lavalette: six-towered castle and local produce market

highlights: Cité de la BD and Angoulême's painted walls
La Rochefoucauld Renaissance Castle (1,000 years of history)
Cellars of the great cognac houses: Hennessy, Martell, Rémy Martin
Aubeterre monolithic church, Europe's largest
Cruise or canoe on the Charente
Village of Verteuil and its mill at the foot of the castle

itineraries.title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge
itineraries.subtitle: From La Rochelle's medieval towers to Vauban citadels, between luminous islands and wild estuary

visits.text: The three towers of the Old Port are remnants of La Rochelle's medieval fortifications. The Saint-Nicolas Tower (14th century), slightly tilted like Pisa, rises to 37 meters. A chain once linked it to the Chain Tower to close the harbor each evening – the original chain is visible at the tower's base.

The Lantern Tower, with its 55-meter octagonal Gothic spire, served as both lighthouse and prison. Some 600 graffiti carved by English, Spanish and Dutch corsairs adorn its walls – ships, figures, and even a locomotive. Rabelais mentions it in his Fifth Book.

La Rochelle's Old Port was the largest port on the Atlantic coast in the 15th century. Stroll along Cours des Dames and Quai Duperré, lined with café terraces. In the evening, the illuminated towers reflect in the basin – one of the most beautiful scenes on the French coast.

The arcades of the city center have sheltered passersby since the Middle Ages. Over 3 km of covered galleries line the shopping streets. Under stone and wooden vaults, half-timbered houses and Renaissance mansions tell the story of the wealthy Rochelais shipowners.

activities.text: Visit of La Rochelle's three towers. A single ticket grants access to all three monuments. Climbing to the top of Saint-Nicolas Tower offers a complete panorama over the port and roadstead. Allow 2 hours for the full visit.

practical_info.note: Saint-Nicolas Tower closed for renovation (check before visiting)

activities.text: Walk along the rampart walkway between the Chain Tower and Lantern Tower. This section of rampart, called 'Rue sur les Murs', overlooks the Saint-Jean-d'Acre esplanade and offers stunning views of the port.

La Rochelle central market. Under the wrought iron and wooden halls, producers sell Marennes-Oléron oysters, Pineau des Charentes, mogettes (white beans) and tourteau fromager. Lively atmosphere every morning.

practical_info.when: Every morning until 1:30pm, best on Wednesday and Saturday

visits.text: La Rochelle Aquarium is one of the largest private aquariums in Europe. Over 12,000 marine animals in 3 million liters of water. The shark tank and jellyfish gallery are spectacular. Allow 2 to 3 hours for the visit.

The New World Museum occupies Hôtel Fleuriau, an 18th-century shipowner's mansion. Collections on the triangular trade, the French West Indies and the slave trade. An unflinching look at La Rochelle's wealth built on slavery.

The Gabut district, a former bastion converted into a colorful village. Brightly painted wooden houses, artists' studios, terraces facing the marina. An unexpected Scandinavian atmosphere on the Atlantic shore.

activities.text: The Sea Bus and the Ferry connect both sides of the port. A 5-minute crossing, a pleasant alternative to walking around. The electric ferry operates year-round.

Concurrence Beach, the closest to the city center. Fine sand, calm water, view of the towers. Lifeguarded in summer. The Mail promenade lined with tamarisk trees runs along the coast toward Les Minimes.
Yellow bike rental (Yélo) self-service. La Rochelle pioneered bike-sharing in France. Cycle paths lead to Les Minimes beaches and the marina.

visits.text: The Île de Ré bridge, 2.9 km long, has connected the mainland to the island since 1988. Toll on entry (free on exit). The crossing offers a first view of the salt marshes and the black and white bell tower of Ars-en-Ré.

The fortifications of Saint-Martin-de-Ré, built by Vauban between 1681 and 1691, form a 14 km star-shaped rampart. UNESCO World Heritage since 2008, they could shelter the entire island population during an English invasion. Walking or cycling the ramparts is spectacular.

The port of Saint-Martin-de-Ré, nestled within the fortified walls, has quays lined with terraces. Convicts bound for Cayenne departed from here – the citadel served as a depot. Climb the church tower for a panoramic view of the island.

The Baleines Lighthouse, at the western tip of the island, stands 60 meters tall. 257 steps lead to the top – 360° view over the ocean and island. The name comes from whales that once stranded on this coast. The old Vauban tower (1682) and a lighthouse museum complete the site.

activities.text: Île de Ré by bike: 110 km of cycle paths connect the island's ten villages. Rentals available in every village. The Saint-Martin → Baleines Lighthouse route (15 km) crosses salt marshes and pine forests.

practical_info.rental: Many rental shops in each village

activities.text: Visit the salt marshes of Loix or Ars-en-Ré. Salt workers harvest fleur de sel by hand using age-old techniques. Guided walks in the marshes, explanations of the work and tastings.
Île de Ré beaches: fine sand on the south coast (Bois-Plage, La Couarde), wilder to the north. Fish traps, semi-circular stone walls, catch fish at low tide – an ancestral technique still practiced.

visits.text: The Royal Rope Factory of Rochefort, built between 1666 and 1669, measures 374 meters long – more than the height of the Eiffel Tower. This manufactory supplied ropes to the Royal Navy for two centuries. The International Sea Center presents the arsenal's history and seamanship techniques.

The Hermione, replica of the frigate that took La Fayette to America in 1780, was rebuilt over 17 years in the Louis XV dry dock. The project brought together traditional ship carpentry skills. Visit the ship with explanations about life for the 300-man crew.

The National Naval Museum occupies Hôtel de Cheusses, Rochefort's oldest civilian building. Ship models built at the arsenal, navigation instruments, figureheads. The arsenal produced 550 ships between 1666 and 1927, including France's first submarine (Le Plongeur, 1863).

activities.text: Accro-mâts, in the Louis XV dry dock, recreates the Hermione's masts. A treetop adventure course at 30 meters height to experience the sensations of 18th-century topmen. Spectacular final zip line.

practical_info.age: From 7 years accompanied, from 12 years alone

activities.text: Stroll through the Arsenal gardens: the Garden of Returns, the Navy Garden and the King's vegetable garden. Palm trees, Virginia tulip trees, begonias – plants brought back from maritime expeditions. Peace and shade facing the Charente.

The Rochefort transporter bridge (1900), the last of its kind in France, connected both banks of the Charente by a suspended gondola. Listed as a Historic Monument in 1976, restored between 2016 and 2020. Gondola crossings available.

practical_info.note: Check schedules on the official website

visits.text: Brouage, a citadel asleep in the marshes. Founded in 1555, it was Europe's leading salt port before silting up. Richelieu made it an impregnable stronghold between 1628 and 1633 under Pierre d'Argencourt, then Vauban reinforced the fortifications in 1685. Samuel de Champlain, founder of Quebec, was born here around 1570. Today, 500 inhabitants and an uncanny silence.

The Brouage rampart walk (2 km) offers views over former salt marshes turned bird reserve. Black-winged stilts, egrets and spoonbills nest here. The powder magazines, forge and restored church can be visited.

Marennes, oyster capital. The Marennes-Oléron basin produces 45% of French oysters. The Saint-Pierre church bell tower (85 m) is the tallest in Charente-Maritime. The Oyster City explains aging in 'claires', those brackish water pools that green and refine the oysters.

activities.text: Visit an oyster shack. Producers open their establishments to explain farming and aging. Tasting on site with views of the claires – a glass of local white accompanies the oysters.

practical_info.tip: Prefer months with an 'R' for tasting

activities.text: Walk in the Brouage marshes. Marked trails through former salt marshes. Binoculars recommended for watching migratory birds. The sunset over the pools is memorable.

visits.text: Île d'Oléron, the largest French Atlantic island (30 km long). The free viaduct (1966, 3 km) links it to the mainland. Varied landscapes: pine forests in the south, salt marshes in the north, fine sand beaches on the west coast.

The Chassiron lighthouse, at the northern tip of the island, has worn its black and white stripes since 1836. 224 steps to the lantern – views of Fort Boyard and Île d'Aix on clear days. The spiral garden at the lighthouse's base echoes oyster shell patterns.

Le Château d'Oléron, former stronghold at the island's entrance. The Vauban citadel guarded the estuary. Today, its ramparts house an artisan and local produce market (summer). The colorful port cabins have become artists' studios.

Fort Boyard, oval fortress built between 1801 and 1857 between Oléron and Île d'Aix. Never used militarily, it became famous through the TV game show. No visits inside, but cruises circle it – an iconic silhouette set on the ocean.

activities.text: Cruise around Fort Boyard. Departures from Boyardville or Saint-Denis-d'Oléron. Full circuit of the fort, passing near Île d'Aix. Commentary on construction history and filming anecdotes.

Oyster tasting at La Cotinière port, the leading artisanal fishing port in Charente-Maritime and France's sixth largest. Auction in the morning, tasting shacks in the afternoon. Oléron's 'fines de claire' and 'spéciales' oysters have an incomparable briny flavor.

Île d'Oléron beaches: Grande Plage at Saint-Trojan, Les Saumonards at Boyardville, Vert-Bois in the south. Maritime pine forests stretch to the sand. The little Saint-Trojan train crosses the forest to Gatseau beach.

visits.text: Royan, a seaside resort rebuilt after the 1945 bombings. The 1950s architecture, called 'Les Cinquante Glorieuses', now holds the Ville d'Art et d'Histoire label. Modernist villas, curved seafronts, luminous concrete.

Notre-Dame Church of Royan (1958), a brutalist concrete masterpiece by Guillaume Gillet. A 45-meter elliptical nave, inverted V-shaped vault, abstract stained glass. Controversial at its construction, it is now a listed Historic Monument.

Royan central market, a concrete and glass structure by Louis Simon and André Morisseau (1956). Undulating dome 52 meters in diameter, spectacular natural light. Seafood, orchard fruits, Charentes specialties. One of the finest covered markets in France.

Royan's seafront stretches across 5 beaches: Grande Conche, Foncillon, Chay, Pigeonnier, Pontaillac. Promenade along modernist villas, casino, congress center. Elegant seaside atmosphere facing the Gironde estuary.

activities.text: Guided tour 'Royan 1950s'. The tourist office offers architectural tours with commentary: the Parc district villas, congress center, Protestant temple, bus station. A fresh look at 20th-century heritage.

Grande Conche beach, 2 km of fine sand in an arc. Lifeguarded in summer, surf and sailing schools, terraces facing the ocean. The Cordouan lighthouse, 'Versailles of the sea', stands on the estuary horizon.
Royan-Le Verdon ferry. The 20-minute Gironde estuary crossing offers a unique view of both the Charente and Médoc coasts. Option to continue to Cordouan lighthouse at low tide (guided excursion).

visits.text: Talmont-sur-Gironde, a village of 100 inhabitants perched on a rocky promontory. Listed as one of France's Most Beautiful Villages, it overlooks the Gironde estuary. Lanes lined with hollyhocks, white houses with blue shutters, artisan shops.

Sainte-Radegonde Church of Talmont (12th century), Romanesque Saintonge style, stands at the cliff edge. Its apse overlooks the estuary – the sea has eaten away the cemetery. Sculpted facade, single nave, golden light. One of the most photographed churches in France.

The carrelets of Talmont, fishing huts on stilts equipped with square nets. A traditional estuary technique for catching shrimp, eels and mullet. Some can be rented overnight – a unique sunset experience.

activities.text: Talmont market (summer). In the village lanes, local producers and artisans. Pineau, cognac, jams, soaps. Festive atmosphere on summer evenings with concerts on the square.
Talmont cliff trail. 3 km walk along the estuary, between carrelets and vineyards. View of the Meschers cliffs and their troglodyte caves on the other side of the Gironde.

visits.text: The Arch of Germanicus (19 AD), a two-bay Roman arch that marked the entrance to the bridge over the Charente. Moved stone by stone in 1843 to escape demolition. Dedicatory inscriptions to Tiberius, Germanicus and Drusus Caesar are readable on the attic.

The Gallo-Roman amphitheater of Saintes (1st century) could hold 15,000 spectators. Built into a hillside valley, it retains its tiers, vomitoria and elliptical arena. Summer concerts and shows in this ancient setting.

The Abbaye aux Dames (11th-12th century), the first women's monastery in Saintonge. Romanesque facade sculpted with grimacing heads and fantastic animals. Conical bell tower covered in stone scales. Now a cultural center and home to an early music festival.

Saintes old town stretches between the Charente and the hillsides. Saint-Pierre Cathedral (rebuilt after the Wars of Religion), 18th-century mansions, medieval lanes. Wrought iron halls for the market.

activities.text: Guided tour of Gallo-Roman Saintes. The tourist office offers a complete circuit: Arch of Germanicus, Saint-Saloine baths, amphitheater, archaeological museum. Mediolanum Santonum was capital of the Aquitaine province.

Cruise on the Charente departing from Saintes. Traditional gabares or electric boats head upriver toward Cognac. Meadow landscapes, weeping willows, grey herons. Commentary on the history of cognac river transport.
Pineau and cognac tasting. Regional producers open their cellars for guided visits. Pineau des Charentes, a blend of grape must and cognac, is enjoyed chilled as an aperitif.

seo.h1_title: Charente-Maritime Road Trip: La Rochelle, Île de Ré, Fort Boyard and Roman Saintonge
seo.intro_paragraph: From La Rochelle's medieval towers to Île de Ré's Vauban ramparts, from Rochefort's Royal Rope Factory to Oléron's oyster shacks. Charente-Maritime unfolds its coastline between sleeping citadels, iconic lighthouses and villages perched above the estuary. A journey between maritime heritage and Atlantic gentleness.
seo.seo_hook: Salt crystallizes in the marshes, oysters mature in the claires, medieval towers guard the harbor entrance. Charente-Maritime lives to the rhythm of the tides.
featured_list: La Rochelle: the three towers of the Old Port
Île de Ré: UNESCO Vauban fortifications and Baleines lighthouse
Rochefort: Royal Rope Factory and Hermione frigate
Oléron: oysters and Fort Boyard views
Talmont-sur-Gironde: Romanesque church on the cliff
Saintes: amphitheater and Arch of Germanicus

places_taglines.FR::la-rochelle: three medieval towers facing the Atlantic
places_taglines.FR::rochefort: the Sun King's arsenal and the Hermione
places_taglines.FR::ile-oleron: largest island on the French Atlantic
places_taglines.FR::talmont-sur-gironde: Romanesque church on the cliff edge

practical_context.vehicle_type: Voiture standard (vélo recommandé sur les îles)
highlights: The three medieval towers of La Rochelle's Old Port
Île de Ré by bike: Baleines lighthouse and UNESCO Vauban fortifications
The Royal Rope Factory and Hermione in Rochefort
The citadel of Brouage asleep in the marshes
Île d'Oléron and its oyster shacks facing Fort Boyard
Talmont-sur-Gironde, Romanesque church on the cliff

itineraries.title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route
itineraries.subtitle: Gothic cathedrals, Cistercian abbeys, Sancerre vineyards and artisan villages — Cher blends medieval heritage with the art of living.

visits.text: Bourges Cathedral surprises from the entrance: no transept, five naves stretching in one line for 120 meters. This extremely rare feature for a Gothic cathedral creates a dizzying perspective found nowhere else in France. Built between 1195 and 1230, it rivals Notre-Dame de Paris. The central portal of the Last Judgment deserves a closer look: smiling resurrected souls, grimacing damned, carved with striking realism.

The 13th-century stained glass windows are among the finest preserved medieval collections. In the ambulatory, the Last Supper and Saint John's vision haven't moved in 800 years. The crypt houses the marble effigy of Duke Jean de Berry (1422) and remnants of the rood screen destroyed during the Revolution. Guided tour required, departures every hour.

396 spiral steps in the Butter Tower lead to the panoramic terrace. The climb is steep but the 360° view over Bourges, medieval rooftops and the Berry countryside rewards the effort. You can make out the marshes to the north and the first hills of Sancerre to the east. Access limited to July-August, fixed hours, limited capacity.

The Palais Jacques-Cœur is one of France's finest Gothic civil buildings. Built between 1443 and 1451 by Charles VII's treasurer, it has 43 rooms over 4000 m². Jacques Cœur only slept there 8 nights before his disgrace. The street facade shows two sculpted figures leaning on false windows — they seem to have been watching passersby for 600 years. Inside, the upturned boat-hull roof frame and monumental fireplaces testify to the splendor of the era.

Jacques Cœur's motto — "To a valiant heart, nothing is impossible" — is carved throughout the palace, accompanied by sculpted shells and hearts. The chapel preserves a stained glass window depicting one of his merchant ships. The banquet hall, with its musicians' gallery and fireplace bearing royal arms, gives an idea of the lavish receptions he never got to host.

activities.text: The Archbishop's Garden, attributed to Le Nôtre, offers an open view of the cathedral's chevet. French-style lawns, geometric flowerbeds and shaded benches: the ideal spot for a break after visits. Free access year-round.

Bourges' historic center is easily walkable. Half-timbered houses on rue Bourbonnoux, Hôtel Lallemant (Renaissance), Notre-Dame church with its contemporary stained glass. The cobbled streets around the cathedral have kept their medieval layout.

Les Nuits Lumière de Bourges (mid-June to mid-September): free nighttime route with projections on historic facades. The cathedral, Palais Jacques-Cœur and several private mansions light up at nightfall. Allow 2 hours for the complete circuit.

visits.text: The Château de Mehun-sur-Yèvre was Charles VII's favorite residence — the king who owed his crown to Joan of Arc and died here in 1461, perhaps from starvation following an abscess. Only the north tower and part of the curtain wall remain standing. The tower houses a museum on Charles VII, the Hundred Years' War and the château's construction site, illustrated by the Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry, where the castle appears in all its splendor.

The château once rivaled Chambord in magnificence. Three wings, watchtowers, chapel, gardens descending to the Yèvre. Charles VII brought his court, artists, scholars here. Agnes Sorel, his favorite, lived here. The Duke of Berry's miniaturists painted the castle around 1410: blue roofs, gilded weathervanes, sculpted galleries. Comparison with the ruins shows the extent of revolutionary destruction.

Mehun is known for its porcelain since 1854. Several workshops still operate, some open for visits. Pillivuyt, the most famous, supplied the Élysée Palace. The Pôle de la Porcelaine (closed Mondays) traces two centuries of manufacturing, displays historic pieces and contemporary creations. You can see potters at work and purchase in the shop.

activities.text: The Saint-Martin Collegiate Church (12th-13th centuries) towers over the Yèvre. Romanesque portal, Gothic nave, 16th-century stained glass. Inside, a beautiful polychrome Entombment and the tomb of Charles VII (the king's remains were transferred to Saint-Denis in the 19th century).

Walk along the Yèvre to see old tanneries, mills, washhouses. The river formed the town's economy: tanneries, fulling mills, paper mills. Mehun once housed up to 500 workers. The banks are pleasant, shaded, with views of the castle ruins.

visits.text: Noirlac Abbey is one of the best-preserved Cistercian abbeys in Europe. Founded in 1136, it escaped revolutionary destruction because it was used as a porcelain factory until 1950. The church, cloister, chapter house, dormitory, refectory: everything is intact or faithfully restored. The stained glass windows by Jean-Pierre Raynaud (1976-2011) — blue, white, gray — respect the Cistercian spirit while bringing contemporary light.

The cloister is the abbey's heart. Four galleries surrounding a square garden. Romanesque columns, sculpted capitals, ribbed vaults. The monks walked here in silence, hands in sleeves, eight times a day between prayers. The chapter house, where daily decisions were made, has kept its acoustics: a whisper at one end is heard at the other.

Noirlac hosts classical music concerts year-round, taking advantage of the church's exceptional acoustics. The Rencontres Musicales de Noirlac (June-September) feature baroque, sacred music, contemporary. Check the program: attending mass or vespers sung by a vocal ensemble in this Cistercian setting is an unforgettable experience.

practical_info.tip: Arrive early to visit before the concert

activities.text: The Borne de l'Empire (Empire Milestone) stands 500 meters from the abbey. Erected in 1757, it marks the geographic center of France under the Ancien Régime — equidistant from Dunkirk, Perpignan, Brest and Strasbourg. A Roman milestone, it's become a pilgrimage site for lovers of symbolic geography.

The abbey shop sells products made by monks from other communities: honey, jams, herbal teas, candles. Also books on Cistercian spirituality, sacred music CDs, local crafts. Part of the proceeds supports abbey restoration.

visits.text: The Château de Montrond dominates the Cher from its rocky spur. Built in the 11th century, rebuilt in the 15th, it belonged to the Princes of Condé. The keep, curtain walls and towers offer a good overview of military fortifications from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance. The interior houses the Musée Saint-Vic (archaeology, regional history). Guided tours in summer.

The fortress witnessed major moments in French history. In 1569, during the Wars of Religion, it held against Protestant troops. In 1651, the Great Condé took refuge there after the Fronde. In 1652, the young Louis XIV came to besiege it. The curtain wall still bears traces of cannonballs.

Saint-Amand-Montrond calls itself the "City of Gold." The town has 300 goldsmiths and jewelers, a quarter of French national production. The craft has been present since the 19th century; today it mixes tradition and contemporary creation. Several workshops welcome visitors by appointment. The Cité de l'Or, opened in 2019, explains working techniques, history and showcases creations.

activities.text: The Cher and Berry Canal crosses Saint-Amand. Towpath, locks, canal bridges: a pleasant 5 km walk follows the waterway. You can spot herons, grebes, sometimes a kingfisher. The canal, dug between 1830 and 1840, connected the Loire to the Allier; barges transported coal, wood, wine.

Saint-Amand's Saturday morning market is one of Berry's liveliest. Local producers, cheeses, charcuterie, vegetables, artisan breads. In season, asparagus, strawberries, melons from nearby farms. Also clothing, household goods. Covered market + outdoor stands.

practical_info.tip: Arrive before 10am for the best selection

visits.text: Dun-sur-Auron's belfry is the town's pride. Built in the 15th century, 32 meters high, it dominates the valley. Climb the 120 steps to the top for a panorama of the bocage and Berry Canal. The belfry also houses a small museum on the town's history and the role of belfries in the Middle Ages.

The Saint-Étienne Church (12th-15th centuries) mixes Romanesque and Gothic. Beautifully sculpted portal, nave with broken-barrel vault, 16th-century stained glass. Inside, a remarkable Tree of Jesse and a 14th-century fresco depicting Saint Christopher.

The Berry Canal runs through Dun. Dug between 1830 and 1841, it connected the Cher to the Allier over 261 km with 52 locks. Commercial navigation ceased in 1955; today the canal is used for pleasure boating. Towpath maintained, locks restored. A peaceful walk along the water.

activities.text: Dun-sur-Auron sits at the edge of Tronçais Forest, one of Europe's most beautiful oak forests. 11,000 hectares of centuries-old oaks, some over 300 years old. The Stebbing, Sentinelle and Carré Renard oaks are local celebrities. Numerous marked trails, picnic areas. The forest supplied timber for the Navy under Colbert; today it's managed for quality cabinetmaking wood.

practical_info.tip: September-October for mushrooms and autumn colors

activities.text: The Auron meanders through the town. Pleasant banks, washhouses, old mills. A 3 km loop follows the river and returns via the old town. You might spot ducks, moorhens, sometimes a heron.

visits.text: Sancerre sits on its rocky butte like a ship's prow overlooking the Loire. From the Tour des Fiefs (14th century), the panorama sweeps 360°: Loire Valley, vineyards terraced like amphitheaters, Pouilly-Fumé hills across the river, Morvan on the horizon. The climb is worth it. 183 steps, stunning view at every level.

The old town is lovely to walk through. Stone houses, cobbled streets, hidden passages. The Saint-Jean Gate (15th century) is the last medieval gate standing. The Saint-Père-la-None Church towers over the square; inside, beautiful 15th-century frescoes recently restored. Several viewpoint terraces offer stunning views of the vineyards.

The Maison des Sancerre is the essential stop to understand the appellation. Interactive museum, tasting workshop, vineyard explanation. You'll learn everything about terroirs (terre blanche, caillottes, silex), grape varieties (Sauvignon for whites, Pinot noir for reds and rosés), vinification. At the end, commented tasting of 3 wines. Booking recommended in high season.

practical_info.tip: Book online to guarantee a spot

visits.text: Sancerre has over 300 winegrowers. Many cellars welcome visitors, often by appointment. Some favorites: Domaine Vacheron (organic, biodynamic), Domaine François Cotat (legendary whites), Pascal Jolivet (contemporary cellar, beautiful view). Direct sales, commented tastings. Allow 1h per cellar.

activities.text: Crottin de Chavignol is Sancerre's other star. This small goat cheese (AOC since 1976) comes in 5 stages of aging: fresh, semi-dry, dry, very dry, "stone." Dozens of producers around Sancerre. Visit a farm, watch milking, taste cheese at different stages. The Dubois-Boulay farm in Chavignol opens daily in summer.

The "Route du Crottin" is a 32 km circuit through the Sancerre vineyards. It connects Sancerre, Chavignol, Verdigny, Bué — the four main wine-producing villages. Signs, explanatory panels, viewpoints. Can be done by car or bike (hilly, allow 3-4 hours). Very beautiful in May-June (vines in flower) and September (harvest).

The Loire flows 8 km from Sancerre. Several river ports for walks: Saint-Satur, Saint-Thibault, Tracy-sur-Loire. The banks are wild, the river wide, migratory birds stop here. At Saint-Thibault, the 11th-century Romanesque church is a gem.

visits.text: La Borne is a unique village: 100 potters for 300 inhabitants. Pottery has been practiced here for 600 years, thanks to clay and wood from surrounding forests. In the 1950s, artist-potters arrived, attracted by cheap workshops and creative freedom. Today La Borne is one of France's main contemporary ceramics centers.

La Borne's studios are scattered throughout the village. Most display the "Open Studio" sign; you can enter, chat with the potter, see works in progress. Styles vary: utilitarian pottery, contemporary sculpture, installation art. Every piece is unique. Prices range from €10 (small bowl) to several thousand euros (large sculpture).

The Centre Céramique Contemporaine occupies old barns. Permanent exhibition on La Borne's history and techniques, temporary exhibitions of French and international ceramists. Workshop, kiln, archival photographs. Free entry. The shop offers a good selection if you haven't found anything in the studios.

activities.text: La Borne en Fête, the first weekend of June, is the major event. All studios open, demonstrations, wood-fired kiln, concerts, outdoor pottery market. Over 10,000 visitors. If you're in the area in early June, it's worth the trip.

practical_info.tip: Arrive early Saturday morning to avoid crowds

activities.text: The forest surrounding La Borne is crisscrossed with marked trails. The "Sentier des Potiers" (3h, 12 km) passes kilns, clay quarries, old workshops. Explanatory panels on the history of local pottery. Moderate, forest shade. Start from the village parking lot.

visits.text: Aubigny-sur-Nère is nicknamed "Scottish City." In 1423, Charles VII granted the lordship to Jean Stuart of Darnley, a Scottish captain who came to France to fight the English. His descendants kept Aubigny until 1672. The château, half-timbered houses, street names (Stuart, Darnley, Douglas) recall this surprising heritage.

The Château des Stuarts (16th-19th centuries) mixes Renaissance and classical styles. The interior houses the Auld Alliance museum, recounting Franco-Scottish relations since the Middle Ages. You'll learn everything about the Stuarts of Aubigny, Scots who fought for France, cultural exchanges. Guided tour, free for under 18s.

Aubigny's historic center survived a fire in 1512 relatively well. Many half-timbered houses date from the 16th century. Rue des Dames, rue du Charbon, place Adrien-Arnoux: each street has its share of sculpted beams and corbelled facades. The Maison Ronde, a remarkable 15th-century house, hosts temporary exhibitions.

activities.text: The Franco-Scottish Festivities, every year on Bastille Day weekend, are Aubigny's major event. Pipe bands, kilts, Highland Games (caber toss, tug-of-war), Scottish dancing, whiskies. Over 30,000 visitors, 20 Scottish pipe bands. The parade on Sunday morning is spectacular.

practical_info.tip: Book accommodation several months in advance

activities.text: The Aubigny Pipe Band, founded in 1975, is one of France's oldest civilian pipe bands. Rehearsals Thursday evenings at the château, open to the public. If you've never heard bagpipes up close, it's an impressive experience.

The Auld Alliance Monument, facing the château, honors Scots who died for France. A plaque recalls the links between Aubigny and Scotland — links that endure: the town has been twinned with East Kilbride since 1990.

visits.text: Henrichemont is a 17th-century utopian city. Founded in 1609 by the Duke of Sully, Henri IV's minister, it was meant to be the capital of the Principality of Boisbelle — an independent micro-state where no taxes were paid. The planned layout: a perfect 500-meter square, eight streets radiating from a central square to the city gates. Inspired by Italian ideal cities and Charleville, its contemporary.

Henri IV's assassination in 1610 and Sully's disgrace froze the project. Only the pavilions around the central square were completed. You can recognize Salomon de Brosse's style — the architect of the Luxembourg Palace in Paris — in the pediment facades and ornate dormers. The Hôtel du Bœuf, Hôtel des Monnaies and Maison du Procureur fiscal testify to what should have been.

The Principality of Boisbelle, of which Henrichemont was the capital, remained independent until 1779. No royal taxes, its own justice system, currency minted on site. Louis XV eventually bought back these privileges, ending four centuries of autonomy. A small museum tells this unique story.

activities.text: The "Balade de Sully" is a 4h50 circuit around Henrichemont. You cross oak and beech forests, sleepy hamlets, fish ponds. Cher Pas-à-Pas waymarking. Bring water and a picnic.

From Henrichemont, the Menetou-Salon and Sancerre vineyards are less than 20 minutes away. Menetou-Salon produces whites (Sauvignon) and reds (Pinot noir) in the same style as its neighbor, often at gentler prices. The Château de Menetou-Salon, property of Prince d'Arenberg, can be visited in season.

seo.h1_title: Cher Circuit: Romanesque Berry and Jacques-Cœur Route
seo.intro_paragraph: From Bourges Cathedral (UNESCO) to Sancerre vineyards, via Noirlac Cistercian Abbey, La Borne potters and the Scottish city of Aubigny-sur-Nère: Cher combines Gothic heritage, art of living and rolling landscapes. A 9-day road trip through the heart of Berry.
seo.seo_hook: Flamboyant Gothic, chilled Sancerre, Crottin de Chavignol and contemporary ceramics — Cher holds surprises at every turn.
featured_list: Bourges: UNESCO cathedral and Palais Jacques-Cœur
Sancerre: vineyards, Tour des Fiefs and Crottin de Chavignol
La Borne: potter's village and contemporary ceramics
Noirlac: Cistercian abbey and classical concerts

places_taglines.FR::saint-amand-montrond: City of Gold and Montrond fortress

seo.h1_title: Vienne Road Trip: Futuroscope and Romanesque Heritage
seo.intro_paragraph: Poitiers will enchant you with its Romanesque architecture. The abbey of Saint-Savin will offer you its frescoes. Explore Civray and its hidden chapels and sacred art treasures. Montmorillon hides in the river valley. Past and future embrace harmoniously here.
seo.seo_hook: The Romanesque vault rises toward the light. The frescoed walls breathe prayer. The stone sculpture whispers faith. Vienne bridges the eras, fully customizable.

highlights: Poitiers' exceptional Romanesque architecture with Notre-Dame-la-Grande
The medieval frescoes of Saint-Savin Abbey, UNESCO heritage site
Futuroscope, Europe's unique technology theme park
Medieval castles and fortifications of Chauvigny and Loudun
Richelieu's ideal city, a 17th-century urban planning masterpiece
The religious and artistic heritage of the Gartempe valley
